I am a wannabe dev and I would like to know if anyone (form TL;DR. staff) can comment on how TL;DR. was/is built?
Hum, I did some of the backend dev work for TL;DR. We do use nodejs with a server side template engine, but nothing fancy for me to comment on...
I have noticed that you were forcing users to have passwords longer than 16 characters, yet you only allow lower-case alphanumeric characters... Any reasons why you impose such restrictions?

Sure thing. Thanks for raising the concern btw. Historically, we had many of our users forget their passwords because they were using way too many special characters that themself could not remember. Now, by limiting passwords to numbers and lowercase alphabet characters we are forcing/helping them pick something they can remember. 1/n
We also force them to pick a password that is sufficiently long (16 characters at least). 2/n
Just to illustrate: with 16 characters you have 36^16 combinations of possible passwords. 3/n

And since TL;DR. doesn't care about scalability (yup, we don't), we have implemented a lock around our login route. In other words, TL;DR. only handles one login request at a time, which forces whoever tries to brute-force an account to do it with one attempt at a time. 4/4
Let me guess, you also do store passwords in the clear because it's... more convenient? LoL
Nope, I can assure you that all our passwords are properly store: salted and hashed!!!
To elaborate on what @idrink0xc0ffee mentioned, we do use Bcrypt with 10 rounds of salting, for all passwords with a little trick to make it even more complicated.
Instead of hashing the password only, we append it to the username and hash the result.
OK. Makes sense. Why don't you use ReactJS?
I don't know how to use ReactJS. I am too old to learn it tbh...
